source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: Pressure tubes for CANDU reactors are made from extruded and cold-drawn Zr-2.5Nb alloy. Their microstructure consists of elongated α-Zr grains (0.3 to 0.5 μm thick), containing about 1 atom percent niobium, surrounded by a thin (30 to 50 nm) network of metastable β-Zr phase, containing about 20 atom percent niobium.

evidence_span: In addition to monoclinic ZrO₂, there is evidence for either tetragonal ZrO₂ or the mixed oxide, 6ZrO₂·Nb₂O₅ in the β-Zr oxide.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: Hydrogen depth profiling by $\mathfrak { s } _ { \mathbf { N } }$ nuclear reaction analyses has been used to investigate the diffusion of hydrogen in these oxides.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: The oxide films were implanted with hydrogen and the progressive dispersion of the implanted hydrogen, as a result of annealing, was used to investigate hydrogen diffusion as a function of temperature.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: The nondispersive nature of the implanted hydrogen peaks in the Zr-1Nb oxide after annealing was suggestive of the presence of interconnected porosity in those oxides.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: However, the broadened peaks in the $\bf { \dot { Z } r } \bf { - } \ \ 2 0 N b$ oxide after annealing are indicative of a normal diffusion process in a nonporous medium.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: The implications of these observations will be discussed in terms of corrosion and hydrogen uptake in $\mathbf { \bar { z } r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ pressure tube material.
